questions.text: Which of the following is the type of cell largely responsible for type I hypersensitivity responses?
questions.explanation: Mast cells are central to type I hypersensitivity (allergic reactions). Upon re-exposure to an allergen, IgE antibodies bound to mast cells trigger their degranulation, releasing histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

questions.text: Type I hypersensitivities require which of the following initial priming events to occur?
questions.explanation: Sensitization is the initial exposure to an allergen, during which IgE antibodies are produced and bind to the surface of mast cells, priming them for a rapid response upon subsequent exposures.

questions.text: Which of the following are the main mediators/initiators of type II hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.explanation: Type II hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies that bind to antigens on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix, leading to cell lysis, phagocytosis, or altered cell function.

questions.text: Inflammatory molecules are released by mast cells in type I hypersensitivities; type II hypersensitivities, however, are characterized by which of the following?
options: localized tissue reactions, such as hives
questions.explanation: Type II hypersensitivities are cytotoxic reactions where antibodies directed against cell-surface antigens lead to the destruction of those cells, often via complement activation or antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC).

questions.text: An immune complex is an aggregate of which of the following?
questions.explanation: An immune complex is formed when antibodies bind to soluble antigens, creating a lattice-like structure of multiple antigen and antibody molecules.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common treatment for type III hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.explanation: Type III hypersensitivity reactions involve inflammation caused by the deposition of immune complexes. Anti-inflammatory drugs, such as corticosteroids, are used to reduce this inflammation and tissue damage.

questions.text: Which of the following induces a type III hypersensitivity?
options: release of inflammatory molecules from mast cells
accumulation of immune complexes in tissues and small blood vessels
destruction of cells bound by antigens
destruction of cells bound by antibodies
questions.answer: accumulation of immune complexes in tissues and small blood vessels
questions.explanation: Type III hypersensitivity is caused by the deposition of antigen-antibody (immune) complexes in tissues and blood vessels, leading to complement activation and inflammation.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not an example of a type IV hypersensitivity?
options: Contact dermatitis (e.g., contact with poison ivy)
questions.explanation: Hemolytic disease of the newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis) is a type II hypersensitivity reaction caused by maternal IgG antibodies crossing the placenta and attacking fetal red blood cells. Latex allergy, contact dermatitis, and the tuberculin skin test are examples of type IV (delayed-type, cell-mediated) hypersensitivities.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an organ-specific autoimmune disease?
questions.explanation: Addison disease is an organ-specific autoimmune disease where the adrenal glands are targeted. Myasthenia gravis (targeting neuromuscular junctions) is also organ-specific. Rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis (with psoriatic arthritis) can be systemic.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a systemic autoimmune disease?
questions.explanation: While the autoimmune attack in Type I diabetes mellitus targets insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas (organ-specific), the resulting insulin deficiency leads to widespread systemic metabolic dysregulation affecting multiple body systems. Other options are more strictly organ-specific in their primary manifestations. Classic systemic autoimmune diseases like SLE or rheumatoid arthritis are not listed.

questions.text: Which of the following is a genetic disease that results in lack of production of antibodies?
questions.explanation: Agammaglobulinemia (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia or Bruton's agammaglobulinemia) is a primary immunodeficiency characterized by a severe deficiency or absence of B cells, leading to a lack of antibody production.

questions.text: Which of the following is a genetic disease that results in almost no adaptive immunity due to lack of B and/ or T cells?
questions.explanation: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) encompasses a group of genetic disorders characterized by profound defects in both B lymphocyte and T lymphocyte development and function, resulting in a virtually absent adaptive immune response.

questions.text: All but which one of the following are examples of secondary immunodeficiencies?
questions.explanation: Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a primary immunodeficiency caused by genetic defects in phagocytic cells. HIV/AIDS, malnutrition, and immunosuppression due to infections like measles are examples of secondary (acquired) immunodeficiencies.

questions.text: Cancer results when a mutation leads to which of the following?
questions.explanation: Cancer is fundamentally a disease of unregulated cell proliferation. Mutations in genes that control the cell cycle can lead to cells dividing uncontrollably, forming tumors.

questions.text: Tumor antigens are ________ that are inappropriately expressed and found on abnormal cells.
questions.explanation: Tumor antigens are often altered self-antigens, normal self-antigens that are overexpressed, or developmental antigens re-expressed in adult cells. The immune system may recognize these as abnormal, even though they originate from the host's own cells.

questions.text: Match the graft with its description.

pairs.description: A. donor is a different species than the recipient
B. donor and recipient are the same individual
C. donor is an identical twin of the recipient
D. donor is the same species as the recipient, but genetically different

questions.explanation: Autograft: from self. Allograft: from another individual of the same species. Xenograft: from a different species. Isograft: from an identical twin.

questions.text: Antibodies involved in type I hypersensitivities are of the ________ class.
questions.explanation: Type I hypersensitivities (immediate allergies) are mediated by IgE antibodies, which bind to mast cells and basophils.

questions.text: Allergy shots work by shifting antibody responses to produce ________ antibodies.
questions.explanation: Allergen immunotherapy (allergy shots) aims to induce a shift from an IgE-dominated response to an IgG-dominated response. These IgG antibodies can act as 'blocking antibodies,' preventing the allergen from binding to IgE on mast cells.

questions.text: A person who is blood type A would have IgM hemagglutinin antibodies against type ________ red blood cells in their plasma.
questions.explanation: According to the ABO blood group system, individuals with type A blood have A antigens on their red blood cells and naturally occurring IgM antibodies (isohemagglutinins) against B antigens in their plasma.

questions.text: The itchy and blistering rash that develops with contact to poison ivy is caused by a type ________ hypersensitivity reaction.
questions.explanation: Contact dermatitis, such as that caused by poison ivy (urushiol), is a classic example of a type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity, which is T-cell mediated.

questions.text: The thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin that acts like thyroid-stimulating hormone and causes Graves disease is an antibody to the ________.
questions.explanation: In Graves disease, autoantibodies (thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins, TSIs) bind to and activate the TSH receptor on thyroid cells, leading to overproduction of thyroid hormones.

questions.text: For a transplant to have the best chances of avoiding rejection, the genes coding for the ________ molecules should be closely matched between donor and recipient.
questions.explanation: MHC molecules (also known as human leukocyte antigens or HLAs in humans) are the primary antigens recognized by the recipient's immune system during transplant rejection. Close matching of MHC/HLA types between donor and recipient minimizes the risk of rejection.

questions.text: Because it is a “transplant” that can include APCs and T cells from the donor, a bone marrow transplant may induce a very specific type of rejection known as ________ disease.
questions.explanation: Graft-versus-host disease occurs when immunocompetent T cells in the transplanted donor bone marrow recognize the recipient's tissues as foreign and attack them.

questions.text: Diseases due to ________ abnormalities are termed primary immunodeficiencies.
questions.explanation: Primary immunodeficiencies are caused by intrinsic defects in the immune system, usually due to genetic mutations.

questions.text: A secondary immunodeficiency is ________, rather than genetic.
questions.explanation: Secondary immunodeficiencies develop as a result of external factors such as infections (e.g., HIV), malnutrition, or immunosuppressive treatments, rather than being inherited.

questions.text: A ________ cancer vaccine is one that stops the disease from occurring in the first place.
questions.explanation: Prophylactic cancer vaccines are designed to prevent cancer from developing, often by targeting oncogenic viruses (e.g., HPV vaccine for cervical cancer) or tumor-associated antigens in high-risk individuals.

questions.text: A ________ cancer vaccine is one that will help to treat the disease after it has occurred.
questions.explanation: Therapeutic cancer vaccines are designed to stimulate the patient's immune system to recognize and attack existing cancer cells.

questions.text: Although both type I and type II hypersensitivities involve antibodies as immune effectors, different mechanisms are involved with these different hypersensitivities. Differentiate the two.
questions.answer:
Type I hypersensitivity (allergy/anaphylaxis) is mediated by IgE antibodies. Initial exposure (sensitization) leads to IgE production, which binds to Fc receptors on mast cells and basophils. Upon re-exposure, the allergen cross-links these IgE molecules, triggering degranulation and release of inflammatory mediators (histamine, leukotrienes). The antigens are typically soluble allergens.
Type II hypersensitivity (cytotoxic) is mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies that bind to antigens on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix. This binding leads to cell destruction via complement activation (e.g., MAC formation), opsonization and phagocytosis, or antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC). The antigens are cell-bound or matrix-associated.
questions.explanation: Type I: IgE-mediated, mast cell degranulation upon allergen re-exposure, soluble antigens. Type II: IgG/IgM-mediated, antibodies bind to cell surface/matrix antigens leading to cell lysis/phagocytosis/ADCC.

questions.text: What types of antibodies are most common in type III hypersensitivities, and why?
questions.answer: IgG antibodies are most common in type III hypersensitivities. This is because IgG is the most abundant antibody isotype in serum and is readily produced during secondary immune responses. When there is an excess of soluble antigen, IgG antibodies form small immune complexes (antigen-antibody aggregates) that are not efficiently cleared by phagocytes. These small complexes can deposit in tissues (e.g., blood vessel walls, kidney glomeruli, joints), where they activate complement, leading to inflammation and tissue damage. IgM can also form immune complexes, but IgG complexes are more frequently implicated due to their size and persistence.
questions.explanation: IgG is most common because it's abundant and forms small, persistent immune complexes with soluble antigens that deposit in tissues, activating complement and causing inflammation.

questions.text: Why is a parent usually a better match for transplanted tissue to a donor than a random individual of the same species?
questions.answer: A parent is usually a better match because Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) genes (called HLA genes in humans), which encode the primary antigens responsible for transplant rejection, are inherited from both parents. An individual inherits one set of HLA alleles from their mother and one set from their father (haplotypes). Therefore, a child will share at least one HLA haplotype (half of their HLA antigens) with each parent. While not a perfect match (unless the parents happen to share HLA types, which is rare), this 50% match is generally much closer than a match with a random, unrelated individual, reducing the likelihood and severity of rejection.
questions.explanation: Individuals inherit one set of MHC/HLA genes (a haplotype) from each parent. Thus, a parent and child will always share at least one haplotype (a 50% match), which is generally better than a match with an unrelated individual.

questions.text: Compare the treatments for primary and secondary immunodeficiencies.
questions.answer:
Primary immunodeficiencies are genetic and often require lifelong management. Treatments include: 1. Replacement therapy (e.g., immunoglobulin infusions for antibody deficiencies, enzyme replacement). 2. Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) for severe combined immunodeficiencies (SCID) or other severe defects. 3. Gene therapy (experimental for some conditions). 4. Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infections.
Secondary immunodeficiencies are acquired. Treatment focuses on: 1. Addressing the underlying cause (e.g., antiretroviral therapy for HIV/AIDS, nutritional support for malnutrition, discontinuing immunosuppressive drugs if possible). 2. Managing and preventing infections (e.g., prophylactic antibiotics). 3. Supporting the immune system if possible (e.g., sometimes immunoglobulin therapy).
questions.explanation: Primary (genetic): Lifelong management, e.g., immunoglobulin replacement, HSCT, gene therapy. Secondary (acquired): Treat underlying cause (e.g., antivirals for HIV, nutritional support), manage/prevent infections.

questions.text: How can tumor antigens be effectively targeted without inducing an autoimmune (anti-self) response?
questions.answer: Effective targeting relies on identifying tumor-specific antigens (TSAs) or tumor-associated antigens (TAAs) that are either unique to cancer cells or significantly overexpressed compared to normal cells. Strategies include: 1. Targeting mutated self-proteins (neoantigens) that are truly foreign to the normal immune system. 2. Targeting oncofetal antigens that are expressed during fetal development but silenced in normal adult tissues. 3. Targeting antigens from oncogenic viruses (e.g., HPV E6/E7 proteins). 4. Using approaches that enhance the immune response specifically at the tumor site or that target regulatory mechanisms that suppress anti-tumor immunity (e.g., checkpoint inhibitors). The goal is to break tolerance to the tumor while maintaining tolerance to normal self-tissues, which is a significant challenge.
questions.explanation: Targeting focuses on tumor-specific antigens (TSAs, e.g., neoantigens from mutations) or tumor-associated antigens (TAAs, e.g., overexpressed or oncofetal antigens) that are minimally expressed on normal cells. Strategies aim to direct the immune response specifically to these, or to overcome local tumor immunosuppression.

questions.text: Patients are frequently given instructions to avoid allergy medications for a period of time prior to allergy testing. Why would this be important?
questions.answer: Allergy medications, particularly antihistamines, work by blocking the effects of histamine, a key mediator released by mast cells during an allergic reaction (type I hypersensitivity). Allergy testing (e.g., skin prick tests) relies on observing the local inflammatory response (wheal and flare) caused by histamine release when an allergen is introduced. If a patient is taking allergy medication, these drugs will suppress or prevent the histamine-mediated reaction, even if the patient is truly allergic to the tested substance. This would lead to false-negative results, making it difficult to accurately identify the patient's allergens.
questions.explanation: Allergy medications (like antihistamines) block the inflammatory response that allergy tests aim to provoke. Taking them before testing can lead to false-negative results, as the medication would suppress the visible signs of an allergic reaction (e.g., wheal and flare in skin tests).

questions.text: In some areas of the world, a tuberculosis vaccine known as bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) is used. It is not used in the United States. Every person who has received this vaccine and mounted a protective response will have a positive reaction in a tuberculin skin test. Why? What does this mean for the usefulness of this skin test in those countries where this vaccine is used?
questions.answer:
The BCG vaccine is a live attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis, which is closely related to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (the cause of TB). A protective immune response to BCG involves the development of cell-mediated immunity (T-cell response) against mycobacterial antigens. The tuberculin skin test (TST, or Mantoux test) works by injecting tuberculin purified protein derivative (PPD), which contains antigens from M. tuberculosis. In individuals previously sensitized to mycobacterial antigens (either through BCG vaccination or actual M. tuberculosis infection), these T cells will recognize the PPD antigens and mount a delayed-type hypersensitivity (type IV) reaction, resulting in a positive skin test (induration).

This means that in countries where BCG vaccination is common, a positive TST is not a reliable indicator of active M. tuberculosis infection, as it cannot distinguish between immunity due to vaccination and immunity due to infection. Therefore, the specificity and positive predictive value of the TST for diagnosing TB infection are reduced in BCG-vaccinated populations. Other diagnostic methods, such as interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), which are less affected by BCG vaccination status, or chest X-rays and sputum cultures, become more important for diagnosing active TB disease in these settings.
questions.explanation: BCG vaccine sensitizes the immune system to mycobacterial antigens, similar to an actual TB infection. The tuberculin skin test detects this sensitization. Thus, BCG-vaccinated individuals will test positive, making the skin test less useful for diagnosing new TB infections in vaccinated populations, as it can't distinguish between vaccine-induced immunity and actual infection. Other tests like IGRAs are preferred.
